channel.title: SiPhox Health Research Team – SiPhox Health

item.title: Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)? Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) is a calculated value derived from your HbA1c (hemoglobin A1c) test results. While HbA1c is reported as a percentage, eAG translates that percentage into the same units used by home blood glucose meters: milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or millimoles per liter (mmol/L). This conversion makes… Continue reading Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)
item.content:encoded:
What is Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)?

Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) is a calculated value derived from your HbA1c (hemoglobin A1c) test results. While HbA1c is reported as a percentage, eAG translates that percentage into the same units used by home blood glucose meters: milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or millimoles per liter (mmol/L). This conversion makes it easier for people to understand their long-term blood sugar control in relation to the numbers they see during daily glucose monitoring. The formula used to calculate eAG was established by the A1c-Derived Average Glucose (ADAG) study, which included 507 subjects from 10 international centers: eAG (mg/dL) = (28.7 x A1C) – 46.7.

Why is Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) important?

Tracking your eAG helps you understand your average blood sugar levels over the past two to three months, providing valuable insight into how well your diabetes management plan is working. Unlike a single fasting glucose test, eAG reflects glucose levels throughout the day, including after meals and overnight. This comprehensive view makes eAG a useful tool for both patients and healthcare providers when assessing glycemic control.

High eAG values indicate chronically elevated blood sugar, which increases the risk of diabetes complications such as cardiovascular disease, kidney damage (nephropathy), nerve damage (neuropathy), and eye problems (retinopathy). Symptoms of consistently high blood sugar may include increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision, and slow-healing wounds. Low eAG values in people with diabetes may indicate well-controlled blood sugar, but excessively low values could suggest frequent hypoglycemic episodes, which can be dangerous and may cause confusion, shakiness, sweating, and in severe cases, loss of consciousness. If you are concerned about your eAG levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my Estimated Average Glucose (eAG) levels?

According to the American Diabetes Association and MedlinePlus:

  • Normal (non-diabetic): 70-126 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C of 4-6%)
  • Prediabetes range: 117-137 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C of 5.7-6.4%)
  • Diabetes target for most adults: <154 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C <7%)
  • Diabetes diagnosis threshold: >140 mg/dL (corresponds to A1C >6.5%)

Common A1C to eAG conversions:

  • A1C 5%: eAG 97 mg/dL
  • A1C 6%: eAG 126 mg/dL
  • A1C 7%: eAG 154 mg/dL
  • A1C 8%: eAG 183 mg/dL
  • A1C 9%: eAG 212 mg/dL
  • A1C 10%: eAG 240 mg/dL

It is important to note that your eAG may not match the average of your home glucose meter readings. This is because most people tend to check their blood sugar before meals or when they feel low, which does not capture post-meal spikes or overnight glucose levels. eAG provides a more complete picture of your 24-hour glucose exposure.

Certain conditions and medications can affect the accuracy of eAG calculations, including anemia, kidney disease, sickle cell disease, thalassemia, and recent blood transfusions. If you have any of these conditions, discuss with your healthcare provider how to best interpret your results.

How can I maintain optimal eAG levels?

If you need to maintain or improve your eAG levels, consider the following strategies:

Dietary Changes: Focus on a balanced diet rich in fiber from vegetables, whole grains, and legumes. Limit refined carbohydrates, sugary beverages, and ultra-processed foods. The American Diabetes Association recommends following the Diabetes Plate Method: fill half your plate with non-starchy vegetables, one quarter with lean protein, and one quarter with whole grains or starchy foods. Pairing carbohydrates with protein, fiber, and healthy fats can help prevent blood sugar spikes.

Physical Activity: Regular exercise improves insulin sensitivity and helps your body use glucose more efficiently. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week, such as brisk walking, swimming, or cycling. Incorporating two to three sessions of resistance training weekly can further improve blood sugar control. Physical activity can lower blood glucose for up to 24 hours after your workout.

Lifestyle Changes: Managing stress through meditation, yoga, or deep breathing exercises can help lower blood sugar, as stress hormones cause glucose levels to rise. Prioritize quality sleep of seven to nine hours per night, as poor sleep negatively impacts blood sugar regulation. If you smoke, quitting can significantly improve your diabetes management and reduce the risk of complications.

Medication Adherence: If your healthcare provider has prescribed diabetes medications or insulin, take them exactly as directed. Missing doses can lead to blood sugar fluctuations that will raise your eAG over time. Discuss any concerns about side effects or costs with your doctor before making changes.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Estimated Average Glucose (eAG)
  • American Diabetes Association – A1C and eAG Conversion Calculator
  • Diabetes Care – Translating the A1C Assay Into Estimated Average Glucose Values (Nathan et al., 2008)
  • National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program – HbA1c and eAG

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your eAG results and for personalized diabetes management recommendations.

item.title: % Free Testosterone
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is % free testosterone? Testosterone circulates in the blood in three forms: tightly bound to sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), weakly bound to albumin, and unbound (free). Percent free testosterone (% free testosterone) is a calculated value that represents the ratio of free testosterone to total testosterone in your blood. While free testosterone typically accounts… Continue reading % Free Testosterone
item.content:encoded:
What is % free testosterone?

Testosterone circulates in the blood in three forms: tightly bound to sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), weakly bound to albumin, and unbound (free). Percent free testosterone (% free testosterone) is a calculated value that represents the ratio of free testosterone to total testosterone in your blood. While free testosterone typically accounts for only 1-3% of total testosterone in men and less than 1% in women, this small fraction is critically important because it represents the biologically active form of the hormone that can readily enter cells and exert its effects.

Why is % free testosterone important?

Tracking your % free testosterone provides valuable insight into how much testosterone is actually available for your body to use, beyond what a total testosterone test alone can reveal. This measurement is particularly useful when total testosterone levels appear normal but symptoms of testosterone deficiency persist. Because of its clinical significance, % free testosterone may be included in comprehensive hormone panels offered by SiPhox Health.

A low % free testosterone may indicate that too much testosterone is bound to SHBG, leaving insufficient active hormone available to tissues. This can occur even when total testosterone is within normal range. Conditions associated with elevated SHBG include hyperthyroidism, liver disease, and aging. Symptoms of low bioavailable testosterone may include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, fatigue, depression, reduced muscle mass, and decreased bone density. A high % free testosterone may indicate low SHBG levels, which can be seen in obesity, insulin resistance, hypothyroidism, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) in women. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my % free testosterone levels?

Adult Males:

  • Low: <1.0%
  • Normal: 1.0-2.7%
  • Optimal: 2.0-3.0%
  • High: >3.0%

Adult Females:

  • Low: <0.3%
  • Normal: 0.3-1.0%
  • High: >1.0%

Percent free testosterone is typically calculated using measurements of total testosterone, SHBG, and albumin through validated formulas such as the Vermeulen equation. This calculation provides a reliable estimate of free testosterone without requiring the more complex and expensive direct measurement methods like equilibrium dialysis.

It is important to interpret % free testosterone in conjunction with total testosterone and SHBG levels for a complete picture of hormonal status. Testing should be performed in the morning (between 8-10 a.m.) when testosterone levels are highest. As SHBG tends to increase with age, the % free testosterone often becomes a more reliable indicator of testosterone availability than total testosterone in older individuals.

How can I maintain optimal % free testosterone levels?

If you need to maintain or adjust your % free testosterone levels, consider the following strategies:

Exercise: Resistance training and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) have been shown to support healthy testosterone levels. Regular physical activity can also help optimize body composition, which influences SHBG levels.

Weight Management: Maintaining a healthy body weight is crucial, as obesity is associated with lower SHBG and altered testosterone metabolism. Weight loss in overweight individuals can help normalize hormone balance.

Nutrition: Ensure adequate intake of zinc, vitamin D, and magnesium, which support testosterone production. Protein intake influences SHBG levels, and a balanced diet with adequate healthy fats supports overall hormone health.

Lifestyle: Prioritize 7-9 hours of quality sleep per night, as sleep deprivation negatively impacts testosterone production. Manage stress levels, as chronic stress elevates cortisol which can affect testosterone. Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Testosterone Levels Test
  • MedlinePlus – SHBG Blood Test
  • Cleveland Clinic – Testosterone Test
  • NIH PMC – Reference Ranges for Testosterone in Men (Framingham Heart Study)

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your % free testosterone results and for personalized hormone health recommendations.

item.title: Transform Your Biomarkers Into Action: 30-Minute Health Coaching Calls
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: You’ve received your blood work results. Now what? Those pages of numbers and medical terminology can feel overwhelming—but they’re actually a treasure map to better health. The question is: how do you turn raw data into meaningful change? That’s where Siphox’s personalized health coaching comes in. For just $39, you get a dedicated 30-minute consultation… Continue reading Transform Your Biomarkers Into Action: 30-Minute Health Coaching Calls
item.content:encoded:
You’ve received your blood work results. Now what?

Those pages of numbers and medical terminology can feel overwhelming—but they’re actually a treasure map to better health. The question is: how do you turn raw data into meaningful change?

That’s where Siphox’s personalized health coaching comes in. For just $39, you get a dedicated 30-minute consultation with an expert health coach who will decode your biomarkers and create a customized action plan designed specifically for you.

What You Get: More Than Just a Conversation

Your health coaching session includes two powerful components:

1. A 30-Minute Live Consultation Talk directly with a qualified health coach who will review your biomarkers, understand your lifestyle and goals, and answer your questions in real-time.

2. A Written Action Plan After your call, you’ll receive a detailed written summary including:

  • Overview of what was discussed
  • Analysis of your key biomarkers and what they mean
  • Specific, prioritized action items tailored to your results
  • Clear next steps to implement immediately

This isn’t generic advice—it’s a personalized roadmap created just for you.

What Happens During Your 30-Minute Call

Before the Call Your coach reviews your biomarker results and prepares to discuss the most important findings for your specific situation.

During the Call (30 minutes)

  • Introduction and Goals (5 min): Share your health objectives, current lifestyle, and any concerns
  • Biomarker Review (10-15 min): Your coach explains your key results in plain English, highlighting what’s optimal, what needs attention, and why
  • Lifestyle Discussion (5-10 min): Review your current diet, exercise, sleep, stress levels, and supplements
  • Q&A and Recommendations (5-10 min): Ask questions and receive initial guidance on next steps

After the Call Following the call, you’ll receive your written action plan documenting everything discussed, with clear action items ranked by priority.

Why This Works: The Science of Personalized Coaching

Context-Aware Analysis A slightly elevated marker might be insignificant for one person but concerning for another. Your coach considers your complete picture—age, lifestyle, goals, and health history—not just reference ranges.

Prioritized Interventions When multiple biomarkers need attention, where do you start? Your coach helps you focus on the changes that will have the biggest impact first, creating momentum rather than overwhelm.

Sustainable Action Steps Generic advice fails because it doesn’t fit your real life. Your action plan accounts for your schedule, preferences, and constraints—making it something you’ll actually follow.

Written Documentation Having your action plan in writing means you can refer back to it anytime, share it with your doctor, and track your progress over time.

Common Areas Your Coach Will Address

Depending on your biomarkers and goals, your coaching session may cover:

  • Metabolic Health: Blood sugar regulation, insulin sensitivity, lipid profiles
  • Hormonal Balance: Thyroid function, sex hormones, stress hormones
  • Cardiovascular Health: Cholesterol management, blood pressure, inflammatory markers
  • Nutrition Strategy: Dietary patterns, macronutrient balance, meal timing
  • Exercise Programming: Cardio vs. strength training, exercise intensity and frequency
  • Sleep Optimization: Sleep duration, quality, and circadian rhythm
  • Stress Management: Cortisol regulation, recovery strategies
  • Strategic Supplementation: Which supplements to take, dosing, and timing

Is Health Coaching Right for You?

This service is perfect if you:

✓ Have bloodwork results but feel unsure how to improve them

✓ Want expert guidance without committing to ongoing coaching

✓ Have specific questions about your biomarkers

✓ Need help prioritizing which health changes to make first

✓ Want a personalized plan you can implement on your own

✓ Value data-driven recommendations over generic advice

✓ Are ready to take action but need clear direction

Get Started Today: Just $39

For less than the cost of a nice dinner, you can gain clarity on your health and receive a personalized action plan from an expert coach.

Here’s what you get for $39:

  • 30-minute one-on-one consultation with a qualified health coach
  • Review of your complete biomarker panel
  • Personalized analysis of your results
  • Written action plan with specific, prioritized recommendations
  • Clear next steps you can implement immediately

Your biomarkers tell a story. Let us help you write the next chapter.

Schedule Your Health Coaching Call Today

Have questions about scheduling or what to expect? Check out our FAQ or contact our support team.

item.title: Longevity and Allergy Panels
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: Longevity/Longevity+ What These Panels Cover The SiPhox Longevity and Longevity+ panels give you a comprehensive look into your long-term health. They measure biomarkers tied to: Heart health – lipids, inflammatory markers, and cardiovascular risk factors Metabolic health – glucose regulation, insulin sensitivity, and key hormones Nutritional status – vitamins and minerals that support energy and… Continue reading Longevity and Allergy Panels
item.content:encoded:
Longevity/Longevity+

What These Panels Cover

The SiPhox Longevity and Longevity+ panels give you a comprehensive look into your long-term health. They measure biomarkers tied to:

  • Heart health – lipids, inflammatory markers, and cardiovascular risk factors
  • Metabolic health – glucose regulation, insulin sensitivity, and key hormones
  • Nutritional status – vitamins and minerals that support energy and cellular repair
  • Inflammation and aging – markers that influence longevity and disease risk

How Longevity+ differs: The core Longevity panel covers foundational markers for cardiovascular, metabolic, nutritional, and inflammatory health. Longevity+ builds on that by adding 60+ extra biomarkers spanning advanced lipids and cardiovascular risk, broader metabolic and endocrine hormones, longevity and cellular-aging cues, and a dedicated toxicology suite (including heavy metals and other environmental exposures). In short, Longevity+ turns a strong baseline view into a deep, systems-level assessment that can uncover hidden drivers of risk and rate-limiters for performance and healthy aging.

The Testing Process

  1. Purchase – Order your panel directly through SiPhox Health.
  2. Lab Visit – Schedule a convenient blood draw at your nearest Labcorp location.
  3. Processing Timeline
    • Most biomarkers return quickly. The first batch of results (covering standard panels) is usually ready in ~5 business days.
    • Specialized markers, such as heavy metals, require more complex analysis and typically arrive in ~10 business days.
  4. Results Access – All results are delivered digitally through the SiPhox platform, with clear explanations and personalized insights.

Why It Matters

These panels help identify risk factors early, giving you the opportunity to take targeted steps toward better cardiovascular, metabolic, and overall longevity outcomes. For those who want the fullest picture, Longevity+ goes a step further by addressing hidden toxic exposures.

Allergy

What the Panel Measures

The SiPhox Allergy Panel measures IgE antibodies to food and environmental allergens and reports Total IgE to help contextualize overall allergy load. Results for each allergen are grouped into clear categories (negative/uncertain, low, moderate, high, very high) so you can see where sensitization may be clinically meaningful.

Coverage can include up to 295 allergens across 165 sources, spanning:

  • Foods: dairy, eggs, nuts, seafood, fruits, vegetables, grains, spices
  • Environmental triggers: pollen (trees, grasses, weeds), dust mites, molds, pets
  • Other exposures: insect venom, latex, and known cross-reactive proteins

The Testing Process

  1. Purchase – Order your Allergy Panel through SiPhox Health.
  2. At-home sample using the EasyDraw arm collector for a simple, comfortable blood collection.
  3. Processing – The lab analyzes your IgE antibody responses across the allergen panel.
  4. Results Timeline – Reports are typically available within 5–7 business days.

What You Receive

  • Per-allergen IgE values with category bands (negative/uncertain → very high)
  • Total IgE to gauge overall sensitization
  • Grouped summaries to spot patterns across allergen families
  • Notes on cross-reactivity to inform next steps and conversations with your clinician

Why It Matters

Understanding your IgE profile helps identify likely triggers, supports personalized diet and lifestyle adjustments, and provides evidence to discuss with your allergist or healthcare provider. It is a powerful first step in managing allergic conditions and improving daily comfort.

item.title: WBC Esterase
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is WBC Esterase? WBC esterase, also called leukocyte esterase, is an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes) when they break down. It is commonly detected through a urine dipstick test as a screening marker for infection or inflammation in the urinary tract. White blood cells are part of your immune system and help… Continue reading WBC Esterase
item.content:encoded:
What is WBC Esterase?

WBC esterase, also called leukocyte esterase, is an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes) when they break down. It is commonly detected through a urine dipstick test as a screening marker for infection or inflammation in the urinary tract. White blood cells are part of your immune system and help defend your body against infections. When bacteria or other pathogens invade your urinary system, your body sends white blood cells to fight the infection, and these cells release esterase enzymes that can be detected in your urine.

Why is WBC Esterase important?

Tracking your WBC esterase levels helps identify infections and inflammation in your urinary tract, which includes your kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. A positive WBC esterase test suggests the presence of pyuria (white blood cells in urine), which most commonly indicates a urinary tract infection (UTI). UTIs are extremely common, affecting about half of women and a smaller percentage of men at some point in their lives.

A positive result may point to several conditions including bladder infections (cystitis), kidney infections (pyelonephritis), urethritis, or other inflammatory conditions of the urinary system. Symptoms of a UTI may include painful or burning urination, frequent urge to urinate, cloudy urine, pelvic pain, and fever in more severe cases. However, WBC esterase can also be elevated in non-infectious conditions such as kidney stones, interstitial cystitis, or after vigorous exercise. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician for proper diagnosis and treatment.

How can I better understand my WBC Esterase levels?

Dipstick test results:

  • Negative: No leukocyte esterase detected (normal)
  • Trace: Minimal esterase activity, possibly early or mild infection
  • 1+ (Small): Moderate levels of white blood cells present
  • 2+ (Moderate): Higher levels of white blood cells present
  • 3+ (Large): Very high levels of white blood cells present

Microscopic urine analysis:

  • Normal: 0-5 white blood cells per high-powered field (WBC/HPF)
  • Elevated: Greater than 5 WBC/HPF
  • Pyuria: Greater than 10 WBC/HPF, indicating significant inflammation or infection

A negative WBC esterase test is normal and suggests no significant white blood cell activity in your urine. A positive result indicates that white blood cells are present and warrants further investigation. When WBC esterase is positive along with other markers like nitrites and bacteria, it is highly suggestive of a urinary tract infection. However, false positives can occur due to contamination during sample collection or the presence of certain substances in urine. Similarly, false negatives may occur if the urine is too dilute, contains certain medications, or if the infection is caused by bacteria that do not produce significant white blood cell responses.

How can I maintain optimal WBC Esterase levels?

If you need to prevent urinary tract infections and maintain normal WBC esterase levels, consider the following strategies:

Hydration: Drinking plenty of water (at least 6-8 glasses daily) is one of the most effective ways to prevent UTIs. Studies show that increasing daily water intake by 1.5 liters can reduce UTI recurrence by nearly 50%. Water helps dilute urine and flush bacteria from your urinary tract before infections can develop.

Hygiene Practices: Practicing good hygiene is essential for preventing UTIs. Women should wipe from front to back after using the bathroom to prevent bacteria from the anal area from spreading to the urethra. Urinating after sexual intercourse helps flush out any bacteria that may have entered the urinary tract. Avoid using spermicides or diaphragms, as these can disrupt the natural bacterial balance.

Dietary Considerations: While evidence is mixed, some research suggests that consuming fermented dairy products like yogurt, fresh berry juices, and foods high in vitamin C may help reduce UTI risk. Limiting caffeine and alcohol intake may also be beneficial, as these can irritate the bladder.

Lifestyle Changes: Avoid holding urine for extended periods, as this allows bacteria to multiply in the bladder. Wear breathable cotton underwear and avoid tight-fitting clothing in the genital area. If you experience recurrent UTIs (two or more infections in six months), consult with your healthcare provider about additional preventive strategies.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Leukocyte Esterase Urine Test
  • Mount Sinai – Leukocyte Esterase Urine Test
  • Cleveland Clinic – Urinalysis
  • PubMed – Measurement of Urinary Leukocyte Esterase Activity (Research Study)
  • Mayo Clinic Health System – 5 Tips to Prevent a Urinary Tract Infection

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your results and for personalized health recommendations.

item.title: Vitamin B6
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is Vitamin B6? Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in over 100 enzyme reactions in the body. In the bloodstream, Vitamin B6 is measured as pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP), which is the active coenzyme form. The body cannot produce Vitamin B6 on its own, so it… Continue reading Vitamin B6
item.content:encoded:
What is Vitamin B6?

Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a crucial role in over 100 enzyme reactions in the body. In the bloodstream, Vitamin B6 is measured as pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP), which is the active coenzyme form. The body cannot produce Vitamin B6 on its own, so it must be obtained through diet or supplementation. This essential vitamin is involved in amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter synthesis, red blood cell formation, and immune function.

Why is Vitamin B6 important?

Tracking your Vitamin B6 levels helps you understand several key aspects of your health. Vitamin B6 is essential for protein and amino acid metabolism, the production of neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine, and the synthesis of hemoglobin in red blood cells. It also supports immune system function and helps maintain normal homocysteine levels, which is important for cardiovascular health.
Low Vitamin B6 levels may lead to microcytic anemia, dermatitis, depression, confusion, and weakened immunity. Symptoms of deficiency can include cracked and sore lips, inflamed tongue, peripheral neuropathy, and cognitive impairment. Conversely, excessively high levels from supplementation may cause nerve damage (sensory neuropathy), skin lesions, and photosensitivity. If you are concerned about your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

Normal Ranges

Plasma pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP):

  • Deficient: Less than 20 nmol/L
  • Normal: 20-125 nmol/L
  • Optimal: 30-80 nmol/L
  • Potentially excessive: Greater than 125 nmol/L

Vitamin B6 status is best assessed by measuring plasma PLP concentration. Results should be interpreted alongside clinical symptoms and other nutritional markers. Some laboratories may report results in ng/mL instead of nmol/L (conversion: 1 ng/mL = approximately 4 nmol/L).

How can I maintain optimal Vitamin B6 levels?

If you need to maintain or adjust your Vitamin B6 levels, consider the following strategies:
Dietary Changes: Consume foods rich in Vitamin B6 such as poultry, fish, potatoes, chickpeas, bananas, and fortified cereals. A varied diet typically provides adequate B6 for most people. If levels are low, your healthcare provider may recommend supplementation.
Lifestyle Changes: Avoid excessive alcohol consumption, as it can interfere with Vitamin B6 metabolism and increase excretion. Certain medications, including some antibiotics and anti-seizure drugs, may also deplete B6 levels. If supplementing, follow recommended dosages carefully to avoid toxicity from excessive intake.

Where can I learn more?

  • NIH Office of Dietary Supplements – Vitamin B6
  • MedlinePlus – Vitamin B6
  • Nutrients – Vitamin B6 and Its Role in Cell Metabolism and Physiology
  • Mayo Clinic – Vitamin B6

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your Vitamin B6 results and for personalized health recommendations.

item.title: Urobilinogen
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is urobilinogen? Urobilinogen is a colorless byproduct that forms when your body breaks down bilirubin, a waste product created from the natural breakdown of old red blood cells. When your liver processes bilirubin to make bile (a fluid that helps digest food), it releases this bile into your intestines. Good bacteria in your intestines… Continue reading Urobilinogen
item.content:encoded:
What is urobilinogen?

Urobilinogen is a colorless byproduct that forms when your body breaks down bilirubin, a waste product created from the natural breakdown of old red blood cells. When your liver processes bilirubin to make bile (a fluid that helps digest food), it releases this bile into your intestines. Good bacteria in your intestines then break down the bilirubin in bile to create urobilinogen. About 80% of urobilinogen is excreted in your stool, while some is reabsorbed into your bloodstream. Most of the reabsorbed urobilinogen returns to your liver where it is recycled back into bile, and a small amount (less than 1%) is filtered by your kidneys and excreted in your urine, giving urine its characteristic yellow color.

Why is urobilinogen important?

Tracking your urobilinogen levels provides valuable insights into the health of your liver, gallbladder, bile ducts, and red blood cells. Liver function is essential for processing waste products, producing bile for digestion, and maintaining overall metabolic health. A urobilinogen test is typically performed as part of a urinalysis during routine checkups or when liver disease is suspected.

High urobilinogen levels in urine may indicate that your liver cannot properly recycle urobilinogen into bile due to liver disease such as hepatitis or cirrhosis. It can also signal hemolytic anemia, where red blood cells are breaking down too rapidly, overwhelming your liver’s ability to process the increased bilirubin production. Symptoms of liver disease may include jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes), dark urine, clay-colored stools, fatigue, nausea, and abdominal pain.

Low or absent urobilinogen levels may indicate a blockage in the bile ducts that prevents bile from reaching your intestines, or severe liver dysfunction. This can occur with conditions such as biliary obstruction or cholestasis. Symptoms may include jaundice, itching, right-sided abdominal pain, and pale stools. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my urobilinogen levels?

Normal urobilinogen levels in urine:

  • Normal: 0.1 to 1.0 mg/dL (1.7 to 17 µmol/L)
  • Low or absent: Less than 0.2 mg/dL
  • High: Greater than 1.0 mg/dL
  • Requires investigation: Greater than 2.0 mg/dL (34 µmol/L)

It is normal for urine to contain trace amounts of urobilinogen. The test is usually performed as part of a standard urinalysis using a dipstick method, where a chemically treated strip is dipped into your urine sample and compared to a reference color scale. Results are typically available within minutes.

Urobilinogen test results should be interpreted in conjunction with other tests to determine whether your liver, gallbladder, or red blood cells are functioning properly. Slightly elevated urobilinogen does not always indicate a serious problem, as levels can fluctuate based on diet, hydration status, and certain medications. However, significantly elevated levels or low to absent levels warrant further investigation by your healthcare provider.

How can I maintain optimal urobilinogen levels?

If you need to maintain healthy urobilinogen levels, consider the following strategies:

Dietary Changes: Eat a balanced diet with plenty of fiber, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Red vegetables such as tomatoes and radishes may support liver health. Avoid processed foods, refined sugars, and excessive salt, as these can strain your liver. Limit alcohol consumption, as even moderate amounts can damage liver cells and worsen existing liver conditions.

Lifestyle Changes: Stay properly hydrated by drinking 6 to 8 glasses of water daily to help your liver and kidneys remove toxins effectively. Exercise regularly, aiming for 30 minutes on most days, as this helps burn triglycerides and reduces liver fat. Maintain a healthy weight, since excess body weight increases the risk of fatty liver disease. Get adequate sleep, as poor sleep quality and short sleep duration can increase the risk of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Medication and Supplement Management: Review your medications with your doctor or pharmacist, as some drugs and supplements can affect liver function. Use medications responsibly and avoid unnecessary NSAIDs. Be cautious with antibiotics, as they can alter gut bacteria that produce urobilinogen. Avoid exposure to toxins by using protective gear when handling chemicals and working in well-ventilated areas.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Urobilinogen in Urine Test
  • National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute – Hemolytic Anemia
  • National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases – Liver Disease
  • Life in the Fast Lane – Dipstick Urinalysis

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your results and for personalized health recommendations.

item.title: Uric Acid
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is uric acid? Uric acid is a waste product formed when your body breaks down purines, which are natural substances found in certain foods and in your cells. When purines are metabolized, uric acid is produced and normally dissolves in the blood, passes through the kidneys, and is eliminated in urine. While uric acid… Continue reading Uric Acid
item.content:encoded:
What is uric acid?

Uric acid is a waste product formed when your body breaks down purines, which are natural substances found in certain foods and in your cells. When purines are metabolized, uric acid is produced and normally dissolves in the blood, passes through the kidneys, and is eliminated in urine. While uric acid serves as an antioxidant in the body, abnormal levels can indicate underlying health issues or increase the risk of certain conditions.

Why is uric acid important?

Tracking your uric acid levels is essential for identifying and preventing several health conditions. High uric acid levels, known as hyperuricemia, can lead to gout, a painful form of inflammatory arthritis that occurs when uric acid crystals accumulate in joints. Elevated levels may also indicate kidney stone risk, kidney disease, or metabolic syndrome.
Symptoms of high uric acid may include sudden and severe joint pain, swelling and redness in joints (often the big toe), limited range of motion, and recurring attacks of joint inflammation. High uric acid is also associated with increased risk of hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and kidney dysfunction. Low uric acid levels are less common but may indicate Wilson disease, a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my uric acid levels?

Blood uric acid levels:

  • Low: <2.5 mg/dL
  • Normal for men: 3.4-7.0 mg/dL
  • Normal for women: 2.4-6.0 mg/dL
  • Optimal: 3.0-5.5 mg/dL
  • High: >7.0 mg/dL (men), >6.0 mg/dL (women)
  • Risk of gout: >7.0 mg/dL

Uric acid levels can fluctuate based on diet, hydration status, and time of day. Levels may be higher in the morning and lower after meals. Testing should ideally be done while fasting for the most accurate results. Your healthcare provider may order multiple tests over time to establish a pattern, as a single elevated reading does not necessarily indicate a chronic problem.

How can I maintain optimal uric acid levels?

If you need to maintain or reduce your uric acid levels, consider the following strategies:
Dietary Changes: Limit intake of high-purine foods such as red meat, organ meats, certain seafood (anchovies, sardines, shellfish), and alcohol, especially beer. Reduce consumption of sugary drinks and foods high in fructose. Increase intake of low-fat dairy products, cherries, and foods rich in vitamin C.
Lifestyle Changes: Maintain a healthy weight through gradual weight loss if needed, as rapid weight loss can temporarily increase uric acid levels. Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of water throughout the day to help your kidneys eliminate uric acid efficiently. Engage in regular physical activity and manage underlying conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetes.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Uric Acid Test
  • StatPearls – Biochemistry, Uric Acid
  • National Kidney Foundation – Uric Acid and Kidney Health
  • Foods and Supplements That Lower Serum Uric Acid (Clinical study)

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your uric acid results and for personalized health recommendations.

item.title: Total T4
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team

T4, or thyroxine, is the main thyroid hormone produced by the thyroid gland. Once released into the bloodstream, TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T4 and T3… Continue reading Total T4
item.content:encoded:
Now I have enough information to write the Total T4 post. Let me create it in the exact format you specified:

What is Total T4?

T4, or thyroxine, is the main thyroid hormone produced by the thyroid gland. Once released into the bloodstream, TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T4 and T3 (triiodothyronine). T4 exists in two forms: bound T4 (attached to proteins) and free T4 (unbound and able to enter tissues). A Total T4 test measures both bound and free T4 together. About 90% of thyroid hormone circulating in the blood is T4, and most of it is converted to the active T3 form in the liver and other tissues. While bound T4 remains in the bloodstream as a reserve supply, only free T4 can enter cells and exert its metabolic effects.

Why is Total T4 important?

Tracking your Total T4 levels helps assess the health of your thyroid gland, which is critical to your endocrine system. Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism, heart function, digestive processes, muscle control, brain development, and bone maintenance. Because of its significance, Total T4 is included in SiPhox Health‘s Thyroid+ panel.
High Total T4 may indicate hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid gland), which can be caused by Graves disease, thyroiditis, or toxic thyroid nodules. Low Total T4 may point to hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid gland). Symptoms of hyperthyroidism include weight loss, rapid or irregular heartbeat, increased hunger, and anxiousness among other issues. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, cold sensitivity, thinning hair, constipation, and other physical and mental issues. If you are concerned with your levels, it is important to consult with your physician.

How can I better understand my Total T4 levels?

Normal Total T4 Range (Adults):

  • Low: Less than 5.0 mcg/dL
  • Normal: 5.0 to 12.0 mcg/dL
  • High: Greater than 12.0 mcg/dL

Total T4 test results are analyzed in conjunction with other thyroid tests such as TSH and free T4 to determine whether the thyroid gland is functioning properly. It is important to note that Total T4 levels can be affected by medications and conditions that change thyroid hormone binding proteins. Pregnancy, birth control pills, and estrogen can increase Total T4, while testosterone and certain other medications can decrease it. In these cases, free T4 testing may be more accurate.

How can I maintain optimal Total T4 levels?

If you need to maintain or adjust your Total T4 levels, consider the following strategies:
Dietary Changes: Ensure adequate iodine intake from sources like seafood, eggs, dairy products, and iodized salt, as iodine is essential for thyroid hormone production. Include foods rich in selenium (Brazil nuts, fish, mushrooms) and zinc (meat, seafood, nuts) which support thyroid function and T4 to T3 conversion. If taking thyroid medication, avoid consuming large amounts of soy products around the time of medication as it may interfere with absorption.
Lifestyle Changes: Manage stress through techniques like yoga or meditation, as chronic stress can disrupt thyroid function. Engage in regular physical activity including cardiovascular exercise and strength training to support metabolic health. Prioritize quality sleep and maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains to support overall thyroid health.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Thyroxine (T4) Test
  • American Thyroid Association – Thyroid Function Tests
  • Cleveland Clinic – T4 (Thyroxine) Test
  • PMC – The Role of Nutrition on Thyroid Function
  • Cleveland Clinic – Diet for Hypothyroidism

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your results and for personalized health recommendations.

item.title: Total T3
item.dc:creator: SiPhox Health Research Team
item.description: What is Total T3? Triiodothyronine (T3) is one of the two main hormones produced by your thyroid gland. T3 is the more active and potent form of thyroid hormone compared to T4 (thyroxine). Once released into the bloodstream, T3 circulates in two forms: free T3, which is unbound and can enter tissues where it is… Continue reading Total T3
item.content:encoded:
What is Total T3?

Triiodothyronine (T3) is one of the two main hormones produced by your thyroid gland. T3 is the more active and potent form of thyroid hormone compared to T4 (thyroxine). Once released into the bloodstream, T3 circulates in two forms: free T3, which is unbound and can enter tissues where it is needed, and bound T3, which is attached to proteins. A Total T3 test measures both free and bound T3 together, providing a comprehensive view of your thyroid hormone levels. Most of your T3 is bound to proteins, with only a small fraction circulating freely. Your body produces about 20% of T3 directly from the thyroid gland, while the remaining 80% comes from the conversion of T4 to T3, primarily in the liver and other tissues.

Why is Total T3 important?

Tracking your Total T3 levels is essential for understanding your thyroid health and overall metabolic function. T3 plays vital roles in regulating your metabolism, heart and digestive functions, muscle control, brain development, body temperature, and even your mood. In children, thyroid hormones are also critical for proper growth and development.

High Total T3 levels may indicate hyperthyroidism, a condition where your thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone. This can be caused by conditions like Graves disease, thyroid nodules, or thyroiditis. Symptoms of hyperthyroidism may include unintentional weight loss, rapid or irregular heartbeat, increased appetite, nervousness, and difficulty sleeping. Low Total T3 levels may suggest hypothyroidism, though T3 is typically the last thyroid hormone to become abnormal in this condition. Symptoms of hypothyroidism may include fatigue, weight gain, sensitivity to cold, dry skin, thinning hair, and depression. Because Total T3 testing is generally more accurate than Free T3 testing, it is often the preferred method for diagnosing and monitoring thyroid conditions, particularly hyperthyroidism.

How can I better understand my Total T3 levels?

Total T3 (for adults 18-99 years old):

  • Low: Less than 79 ng/dL
  • Normal: 79-165 ng/dL
  • High: Greater than 165 ng/dL

Note: Normal ranges may vary slightly among different laboratories and are age-specific for people under 20 years old. Always check your lab report’s reference range and consult with your healthcare provider about your specific results.

Total T3 test results are typically analyzed alongside other thyroid function tests, including TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) and T4 levels, to provide a complete picture of thyroid function. Your healthcare provider will look at different combinations of high, low, and normal results to determine if a thyroid condition is present. For example, high Total T3 combined with low TSH and high free T4 typically indicates that a problem with your thyroid gland is causing hyperthyroidism.

It is important to note that certain factors can affect Total T3 levels beyond thyroid function. Medications such as birth control pills, estrogen, steroids, and amiodarone can influence test results. Pregnancy, particularly during the first trimester, can also increase Total T3 levels. Severe illness may decrease T3 levels as the body converts T4 into reverse T3 (an inactive form) rather than active T3. Your healthcare provider will consider these factors when interpreting your results.

How can I maintain optimal Total T3 levels?

If you need to maintain or support healthy Total T3 levels, consider the following strategies:

Nutritional Support: Ensure adequate intake of key nutrients that support thyroid hormone production and conversion. Iodine is essential for thyroid hormone synthesis and can be obtained from seafood, sea vegetables, dairy foods, and iodized salt. Selenium and zinc are crucial for the conversion of T4 to T3, with selenium found in Brazil nuts, fish, and mushrooms, and zinc in red meat, seafood, nuts, and lentils. The amino acid tyrosine, a precursor to thyroid hormones, is abundant in meat, dairy, and pumpkin seeds.

Lifestyle Modifications: Several lifestyle factors can support optimal thyroid function. Managing stress is critical, as elevated cortisol levels can inhibit thyroid-stimulating hormone production and reduce T4 to T3 conversion. Regular exercise, particularly in the morning, can help stimulate thyroid hormone production and boost metabolism. Prioritizing quality sleep and addressing any sleep disturbances can also support healthy thyroid function.

Gut Health: Emerging research highlights the connection between gut health and thyroid function. Supporting a healthy gut microbiome through probiotic supplementation and an anti-inflammatory diet may help optimize thyroid hormone levels and reduce autoimmune thyroid conditions. Focus on eating low glycemic foods like green leafy vegetables, berries, and whole grains to help normalize metabolism.

Where can I learn more?

  • MedlinePlus – Triiodothyronine (T3) Tests
  • Cleveland Clinic – T3 (Triiodothyronine) Test
  • Mount Sinai – T3 Test Information
  • Institute for Functional Medicine – Restoring Thyroid Hormone Balance

DISCLAIMER: This information is for educational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always consult your healthcare provider for interpretation of your Total T3 results and for personalized thyroid health recommendations.
